definitions.definition: to become hard, and often turn to ice, as a result of extreme cold; to make something do this

examples.text: Water freezes at 0°C.
It's so cold that even the river has frozen.
The cold weather had frozen the ground.
The clothes **froze solid** on the washing line.
The frost had frozen the ground hard.
Last year's cold spell froze the lake solid.

definitions.definition: if a pipe, lock or machine freezes, or something freezes it, it becomes blocked with frozen liquid and therefore cannot be used

examples.text: The pipes have frozen, so we've got no water.
I kept the car running to stop the engine freezing up.
Ten degrees of frost had frozen the lock on the car.

definitions.definition: when it freezes, the weather is at or below 0° Celsius

examples.text: It may freeze tonight, so bring those plants inside.

definitions.definition: to be very cold; to be so cold that you die

examples.text: Every time she opens the window we all freeze.
Two men **froze to death** on the mountain.
Two men were frozen to death on the mountain.

definitions.definition: to keep something, especially food, at a very low temperature in order to preserve it

examples.text: Can you freeze this cake?
The organ samples were immediately frozen in liquid nitrogen.

definitions.definition: to be able to be kept at a very low temperature

examples.text: Some fruits freeze better than others.

definitions.definition: to stop moving suddenly because of fear, etc.

examples.text: I froze with terror as the door slowly opened.
The smile froze on her lips.
The police officer shouted ‘Freeze!’ and the man dropped the gun.
Suddenly, Ronny seemed to freeze.
He was so surprised he froze to the spot.
Maggie's face had frozen into a cold mask.
She froze with horror when she saw the body.

definitions.definition: when a computer screen freezes, you cannot move any of the images, etc. on it, because there is a problem with the system
to stop a film or video in order to look at a particular picture

examples.text: Freeze the action there!

definitions.definition: to hold wages, prices, etc. at a fixed level for a period of time

examples.text: Salaries have been frozen for the current year.
Prices have been frozen at this level for over a year now.

definitions.definition: to prevent money, a bank account, etc. from being used by getting a court order which bans it

examples.text: The company's assets have been frozen.

definitions.definition: to make you extremely frightened or shocked
to suddenly stop because something has frightened or surprised you

examples.text: Jess froze in her tracks and took a deep breath.

definitions.definition: to suddenly make somebody stop by frightening or surprising them; to suddenly stop because something has frightened or surprised you

examples.text: The question stopped Alice in her tracks.
Suddenly he stopped dead in his tracks: what was he doing?
The disease was stopped in its tracks by immunization programmes.

wordOrigin: Old English frēosan (in the phrase hit frēoseth ‘it is freezing’), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch vriezen and German frieren, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin pruina ‘hoar frost’ and frost.
